conclusion: Determine the condition under which the plank starts to move upward by analyzing forces on block and plank.
The plank is leaning against a smooth vertical wall with a block at the lower right.
Identify forces acting on the block: weight, normal force, frictional force, applied forces F1 and F2.
Calculate weight of the block as W = mg = 8.0 N.
Determine maximum static frictional force as f_max = mu N.
Normal force N is found using equilibrium in vertical direction: N = W cos theta = 8.0 cos theta.
Maximum static frictional force is f_max = 1.6 cos theta.
Block starts to move when W sin theta > f_max, leading to 8.0 sin theta > 1.6 cos theta.
Rearrange to find condition: 5 tan theta > 1 implies tan theta > 1/5.
Angle theta relates to plank geometry: height h = L sin theta, distance d = L cos theta.
Plank starts to move if horizontal component of F1 > frictional force between plank and wall.
Frictional force between plank and wall is f_w = mu N_w, where N_w is normal force from wall.
Normal force from wall is N_w = F2 - F1 sin theta.
Frictional force is f_w = mu (F2 - F1 sin theta).
Plank moves if F1 cos theta > f_w, leading to F1 cos theta > mu (F2 - F1 sin theta).
Need minimum value of F1 for block to start moving, considering tan theta > 1/5.
